title-group.article-title: Analytical research on a single degree-of-freedom semi-active oscillator with time delay

abstract.p: In this paper a single degree-of-freedom semi-active oscillator with time delay is researched. By averaging method, the first-order approximately analytical solution is obtained, and the stability condition is also established based on the Lyapunov theory. The analytical results show that the amplitude and the stability condition of the steady-state solution are all periodic functions of time delay, with the same period as the excitation one. Moreover, another simple case, namely the semi-active oscillator without time delay, is also investigated based on the first-order approximately analytical solution, and the result shows that the steady-state solution in this case is unconditionally stable. The comparisons of the analytical solution and the numerical one are fulfilled, and the results verify the correctness and satisfactory precision of the first-order approximately analytical solution. At last, the selection or design of an appropriate time delay to improve control performance through the first-order approximately analytical solution is studied.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In many engineering fields, vibration control technique is very important to mitigate the unnecessary force and/or displacement in order to guarantee the safe operation of these systems (Harris and Crede, 1976; Moheimani et al., 2003; Inman, 2006). In general, the controlled system could be divided into three kinds, namely the passive, the active and the semi-active control system, based on the realization manner of the necessary control force (Sun et al., 1995; Hrovat, 1997; Jalili, 2002; Casciati et al., 2006; Guglielmino et al., 2008). As we all know, although the passive control system has better reliability and its realization is easy, it is difficult to attain a perfect control performance in the whole frequency range, especially in low frequency range. The active control system has a much better performance than the passive control one, but it needs higher energy consumption and a more complicated structure which limits its extensive application. The semi-active control system fills the gap between the passive and active control system, and could make the vibration control system attain an ideal compromise between performance improvement and simplicity of implementation.

The recent works about semi-active control system are focused on two aspects, namely the semi-active control strategies and the semi-active control devices. There are many semi-active control strategies which have been extensively researched by a lot of scholars, such as the sliding mode control, neural network control, adaptive control, fuzzy logic control, optimal control, etc. Many smart devices, including the electro-rheological (ER) damper (Hidaka et al., 1999), the magneto-rheological (MR) damper (Shen et al., 2006; Potter et al., 2011) and shape memory alloys, are adopted as the actuator in semi-active systems. For example, Laflamme et al. (2011) proposed a wavelet neuro-controller for systems controlled by semi-active devices in large-scale civil structures, and assessed its performance and convergence. Huang and Lin (2007) presented a novel neural network based on sliding mode control to treat the nonlinearity and time-varying behaviors in a semi-active system, and the experimental results verified that this approach effectively suppressed the oscillation amplitude of sprung mass in response to road surface disturbances. Hrovat et al. (1988) studied a semi-active vehicle suspension model considering suspension constraints and ride quality requirements, and obtained the approximate solution based on stochastic optimal control theory. Alanoly and Sankar (1987) proposed a semi-active damper called as semi-active balance control, which should ideally have no damping force, or a minimal damping force, when the spring force and damping force have the same direction. Abe and Igusa (1996) presented analytical research on optimal control algorithms for semi-active absorbers and found that it was suitable to control the impulse response of the structure, and more effective than traditional passive vibration ones. Liu et al. (2008) presented a new configuration using two controllable dampers and two constant springs, and analyzed it theoretically and experimentally. Ahmadian (1999) studied the semi-active vibration isolation system and passive system analytically, and found that the semi-active system may provide good isolation performance at whole frequencies if the damping ratio was sufficiently large. Zhou and Liu (2010) designed a tunable high-static-low-dynamic vibration isolator that was realized by connecting a mechanical spring in parallel with a magnetic spring, that was constructed by a pair of electromagnets and a permanent magnet. Shen et al. (2012) studied the first-order approximate solution and parameters optimization of four semi-active dynamic vibration absorbers analytically.

In vibration control engineering, the unavoidable time delay commonly plays an important role, which arises from both controllers and actuators. Generally speaking, time delay may make the system response more complicated, deteriorate the control performance, or even cause the controlled system to become unstable. On the other hand, the appropriate time delay could improve the control performance remarkably. Hu and Wang (2002) researched the nonlinear dynamics in vibration control systems with time delay in detail, and obtained some important criteria for the stability analysis of the controlled system with delayed feedback. Rohman et al. (2010) found that the critical wind speed with time delay would be less than that without time delay, which might cause the suspension bridge to gallop at normal wind speeds. Lee and Kawashima (2007) proposed a time delay compensation strategy based on the Newmark’s method to mitigate the degradation of control performance due to time delay, which illustrated a superior compensation performance on the time-delayed nonlinear system under semi-active control. Park and Jeon (2002) applied the Lyapunov type robust control to the semi-active vibration control of a controllable seat system with uncertainty and time delay, and the simulation results verified that the robust control considering the time delay of the damper suppressed the seat vibration effectively. Application of time delay, for instance in a dynamic vibration absorber, could be found in the literature (Olgac and Hansen, 1995; Hosek et al., 1999; Jalili and Olgac, 2000; Zhao and Xu, 2007), where the time delay improved the control performance significantly.

According to the authors’ knowledge, little work has been done on the analytical research on semi-active control system, especially when time delay exists therein. Hence, analytical research on a single degree-of-freedom (d.f.) semi-active oscillator with time delay is presented in this paper, where the semi-active balance control strategy by Alanoly and Sankar (1987) is adopted. Detailed analysis is given in Section 2, including the derivation for the approximately analytical solution, the amplitude-frequency equation, and the stability condition. A simple case, named as a single d.f. semi-active oscillator without time delay is also investigated based on the amplitude-frequency equation and the stability condition in this section. In section 3, the comparisons of the approximately analytical solution and the numerical one are fulfilled, and the selection or design for the appropriate time delay in this semi-active control system is illustrated by an example. Finally, the conclusion and summarization are presented.

sec.title: 2. Analytical research on a single degree-of-freedom semi-active oscillator with time delay
2.1. Mathematical model and dimensionless form
sec.p:
The dynamical model of a single d.f. semi-active oscillator is shown in Figure 1. Based on the Newtonian second law, the equation of motion could be established as (1)mx··=k(x0-x)+c(x·0-x·), where x,x0,m,k,c are the system displacement, the external displacement excitation, the system mass, the stiffness, and the adjustable damping coefficient respectively. The damping coefficient is adjusted according to the control strategy (2)c= {cmax(x-x0)·(x·-x·0)≤0cminelse , where the minimum damping coefficient is unequal to zero in many practical engineering. This control strategy was presented by Alanoly and Sankar (1987) and called as semi-active balance control, the aim of which is to mitigate the system acceleration and the transmitted force. sec.title: 3. Numerical simulation
sec.p: In order to verify the correctness and precision of the aforementioned approximately analytical solution and the stability condition, it is necessary to research equation (6) numerically. The selected parameters are: m=240kg, k=16000N/m, cmax=1000N·s/m, A=0.01m.

sec.title: 3.1. Comparison of the approximate solution and the numerical one
sec.p:
The amplitude-frequency and the effective-values-frequency curves as the evaluation criterion are selected, which could present comprehensive judgment in the whole frequency range. The following Figures 2, 3, 4 and 5 correspond to four items respectively, including the single d.f. semi-active oscillator without time delay and ξmin=0, the single d.f. semi-active oscillator without time delay and ξmin≠0, the single d.f. semi-active oscillator with time delay and ξmin=0, and the general case in Sections 2.2 and 2.3. Figure 2.
The response of single degree-of-freedom semi-active oscillator without time delay and ξmin=0: (a) comparison of the amplitude of the approximate solution and the numerical solution where the solid line is for approximate solution and the line with circle is for numerical one; (b) comparison of the effective values of the approximate solution and the numerical solution where the solid line is for approximate solution and the line with circle is for numerical one; (c) the time history for Ω=2.082; (d) the frequency spectrum for Ω=2.082 .
Figure 3.
The response of single degree-of-freedom semi-active oscillator without time-delay and ξmin=0.05ξmax: (a) comparison of the amplitude of the approximate solution and the numerical solution where the solid line is for approximate solution and the line with circle is for numerical one; (b) comparison of the effective value of the approximate solution and the numerical solution where the solid line is for approximate solution and the line with circle is for numerical one; (c) the time history for Ω=2.572; (d) the frequency spectrum for Ω=2.572 .

From Figure 2, it could be discovered that the amplitude and the effective values of the approximate solution agree well with those of numerical solution in low-frequency and resonance range, which illustrate the correctness and high precision of the approximately analytical solution. However, there are distinct errors between the approximate and numerical solution in high-frequency range, especially the amplitude. Selecting excitation frequency Ω=2.082 (ω=17), and plotting the time history and the frequency spectrum, it could be found that there are many higher-order odd sub-harmonic ingredients in the response, that lead to the observed errors in the amplitude-frequency and the effective-value-frequency curves. The existence of multiple higher-order odd sub-harmonic ingredients in the response of semi-active system has also been found by Ahmadian (1999) numerically and experimentally. Similar results could also be found in Figure 3, where ξmin=0.05ξmax and the time history and the frequency spectrum for Ω=2.572(ω=21) are as a typical example.

From the observation of Figure 4, it could be found that the approximate solution agrees much better with the numerical one in almost the whole frequency range except a narrow-band in high-frequency range, where the time delay is selected as τ=0.02. This shows time delay may have similar effect as the damping force, which reduces the higher-order odd sub-harmonic ingredients in the response largely and makes the ingredients in the response much simpler. The reason has been explained and verified in other nonlinear oscillators by Hu and Wang (2002). Selecting excitation frequency Ω=4.287 (ω=35), and plotting the time history and the frequency spectrum, it could be discovered that there are some higher-order odd sub-harmonic ingredient in the response, which are smaller than that of the previous two items so that the curve is much smoother. sec.title: 3.2. Effect of time delay on the amplitude and stability condition of the approximate solution
sec.p: From equations (17) and (23), it could be found that the amplitude and the stability condition of the steady-state solution are all periodic functions of time delay with the same period as the excitation one, which means that an appropriate time delay could be selected or designed so as to obtain the perfect control performance.

As an example, the amplitude and the stability condition of the approximate solution when Ω=4.899 (ω=40) are plotted in Figure 6. It could be found that when τ<τ2,0, the approximately steady-state solution is asymptotically stable, and the smaller the time delay is, the more significant the amplitude is reduced. If the time delay is large, an appropriate τ in [τ1,1 τ2,1] could be selected so as to minimize the amplitude, which would make the control performance much better. From the given system parameters, the time delay is τ1,1=0.214 and the optimal time delay is τopt=1.074in[τ1,1 τ2,1]. sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: The analytical research on a single d.f. semi-active oscillator with time delay is fulfilled by the averaging method, and the approximately steady-state solution and the stability condition are established. It could be found that the amplitude and stability condition for the approximately steady-state solution are all a periodic function of time delay, so that a selection or design method for the appropriate time delay is presented. Finally, the comparisons of the approximately steady-state solution numerical simulations verify these results.
